Award.AwardTitle: Emerging Research-Empirical Research--Evolving Minds: Children's Learning of Natural Selection from Picture Books

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research project is to design classroom-level interventions that will guide students toward a basic understanding of biological adaptation through natural selection using picture books as pedagogical tools of instruction. The proposer engages support from experts in related fields to help develop "tailor-made" picture books to convey complex scientific information to 400 kindergarten through second grade (K-2) students in 32 schools in the Worcester Public School District.

The questions for the study include: (1) whether it is possible to foster a scientifically accurate and productive understanding of adaptation by natural selection in Grades K-2 classrooms using picture storybooks; (2) what the most effective components of such a classroom intervention are; (3) whether complex biological concepts are more accurately learned by young children when explanations are couched in terms of human or in terms of non-human animals; and (4) whether early instruction about the mechanism of natural selection modifies young children's untutored tendency to explain natural entities by reference to function, a teleological bias is at the heart of older students' scientifically inaccurate reasoning.

Building on a NSF-supported pilot study, this research will consist of four individual studies, each building on lessons-learned from the one before. The first three studies will include a pre-test, intervention, immediate, and delayed post-test design to explore individual-level changes in grade K-2 students' learning and generalization about the logic of natural selection. Study four will be a classroom-level intervention whose structure depends on wisdom accumulated from the first three studies. It will involve picture book reading sessions with small groups of children followed by assessments of their learning. These sequential studies will be administered orally by the proposer.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Natural selection is a core mechanism of evolution, the unifying principle of biology, and the process responsible for the functional adaptation of biological organisms. As a cornerstone concept in science, it is a focus of science education in the United States and throughout the world. However, over 30 years of scientific research has shown that, even after instruction, adaptation by natural selection is one of the most widely misunderstood of all processes. The origin of many of these misconceptions can be traced to naturally developing “intuitive” cognitive biases that can be observed at least as early as the primary grades of elementary school. And yet, prevailing assumptions about young children’s cognitive limitations mean that comprehensive and causally coherent instruction on natural selection is typically delayed until 12- to 17-years of age, long after early developing intuitive theoretical misunderstandings are likely to have become entrenched.

In this context, the primary goal of this inter-disciplinary research was to design and explore the viability of a classroom intervention for kindergarten and second grade children that offered basic but comprehensive mechanistic instruction on the counter-intuitive process of within-species adaptation by natural selection. The novel intervention was built around the pedagogical tool of custom-crafted picture storybooks. The intervention approach also incorporated a series of strategies and best practices already known to facilitate learning and transfer such as self-explanation and analogical comparisons across different examples.

An iterative series of design and pre- to post-test storybook intervention studies conducted with samples of children who were individually assessed either in the lab, urban after-schools, and then urban public school classrooms yielded the following findings: Kindergarten and second grade children show significant capacities for understanding complex mechanistic explanations that present deep challenges for older students and adults. Across all samples tested, young children learned and transferred the theory of within-species adaptation by natural selection when taught via carefully designed but relatively circumscribed storybook interventions. Learning gains were most marked in second graders and were observed despite the fact that, in some participant groups, many children were bilingual and entered studies displaying relatively little biological factual knowledge. Furthermore, children’s learning was active and enduring: In classroom-based research, children not only stably generalized their understanding across multiple testing sessions, they also applied it to very different cases than those represented in storybook materials over a month after classroom discussions in which storybooks were analogically compared. These classroom study findings converged with earlier lab-based research that found that, after only one storybook intervention session, children’s generative learning persisted for at least three months.

 In addition to clarifying young children’s explanatory and theory-building capacities, empirical studies conducted under this award also shed light on the nature and development of a series of intuitive cognitive biases with implications for instruction on STEM concepts such as evolution by natural selection. For instance, findings suggested that the ubiquitous and often recommended habit of talking about animal properties in terms of their functional benefits (e.g. “orinas have tepins that help them breathe”) primes conceptual biases that can undermine abilities to represent natural selection by diminishing children’s capacities to represent biological variation.
